titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. V. Tuesday— Read Genesis 1–3.

Thick foggy morning. Cleared away by noon, and almost Summer warmth the remainder of the day— From noon till past three O’Clock we had a succession of visitors— A few members of Congress—a few members of the foreign Legations, and a few private Citizens— In all perhaps a hundred persons—very few Ladies; Mrs Adams being known to be confined to her chamber. I walked round the Capitol-Hill, and the weather was so fine that I met a great number of persons, walking— Among the rest Mr Webster who arrived and took his seat in the Senate, yesterday— We had a company of twelve gentlemen to dine—8 of them Members of Congress— I am occupied in preparing a Report for the Minority of the Committee of Manufactures, upon the part of the President’s Message referred to them by the House.
2. IV.15. Wednesday.

Attended at the Meeting of the Committee of Manufactures. Hoffman absent— All the other members present— There appears to be no disposition in the Committee now to do any thing. I brought up again my proposed Resolution to call upon the Secretary of the Treasury, for an estimate of the deficiency in the Revenue, and of the increased expenditure to be expected in the event of the collection of the impost’s being suspended, and of resistance to the execution of the Laws in South-Carolina. John S. Barbour discussed the point principally with me—all the other members were against me, except Dr Condict; who said nothing; but urged me to offer my proposition as a Resolution in the House— There was some talk among the members of making a Report to the House, approving or disapproving the Bill, reported by the Committee of Ways and Means. Findlay said he thought this Committee would have finally to report a Bill, for he did not think that reported by the Committee of Ways and Means would pass. This was the first indication I had observed, of indecision in the Presidential Ranks— The Committee adjourned till Monday Morning at ten— In the House Edward Everett’s Resolution for reducing the rates of Postage was discussed. Hoffman moved to lay it on the Table, which was opposed by Cambreleng.— No decision— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Verplanck proposed to take up the Tariff Bill, but consented to postpone it till to-morrow— Several appropriation Bills were taken up and laid aside, and Root called up his Resolution, for amending the Constitution of the United-States by giving the Election of the President and Vice-President directly to the People. Hubbard was chairman of the Committee of the whole, and they got into a snarl, about a question whether the Bills were, or were not reported to the House— Adjourned about 3. I spoke to John Davis about the Tariff Bill— He said they expected I should take the field for the Manufactures— I told him I should do nothing but vote against the Bill and all its parts— The manufacturers themselves are all silent and immovable, as if they were struck with a palsy— Mr Webster and Mr Appleton were here this Evening— Judge Henry Baldwin of the Supreme Court of the United States is fallen into Lunacy.
3. V:30. Thursday.

I presented to the House the Petition of William Callender, for compensation for an improvement in Gunnery— Referred without reading to the Committee of Military Affairs. I had presented a similar Petition from the same person at the last Session— Referred then to the same Committee, who did not favour the claim— Edward Everett’s Resolution was laid on the table by the Speaker’s casting vote 89. and 89. on Polk’s Motion— Verplanck offered a Resolution to take up the Tariff-Bill reported by him as Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, next Monday at One O’Clock and every day thereafter till further order of the House— This Resolution by the Rule was to lay over, one day— Verplanck asked unanimous consent to consider it now. objection was made— He moved to suspend the Rule, and for the yeas and nays— They were 106 to 78— Not two thirds and the rule was not suspended—but to-morrow the vote will be carried, and the Bill will pass by about the same majority— The question was renewed, whether the Appropriation Bills were or were not yesterday reported by the Committee of the Whole on the State of the Union to the House— Root after some recalcitration and discussion with the Speaker, finally gave up the point— The Bill for returning certain duties collected by the Tariff Act of 1828 was discussed, but left undecided— Archer came to me, and told me that the communication which he had promised me of the President’s Proclamation and the Documents from South-Carolina, was postponed—
4. IV:15. Friday.

Thomas Flinn, a crippled old man, a Soldier in the army during the last War with Great Britain came to me, with papers for authenticating his claim to a pension— He had no certificate from a Surgeon of his having been disabled by wounds received during the War, though he affirmed the facts to be so. I advised him to go to General Macomb, and the Adjutant General Jones, and to ascertain where the Surgeon, of his Regiment, who attended him now is; and to obtain if possible his certificate— At the House J. W. Taylor introduced to me Mr Hammett, the Chaplain of the House, who told me that he had been already introduced to me when I was President.— The Resolution to take up the Tariff-Bill next Monday and every day thereafter, till further order, came up— M’Kennan of Pennsylvania moved as an Amendment, the first Monday in February, instead of Monday next— He said he wished for time to consult the opinion of his Constituents— Polk immediately moved the previous Question; which cuts off all debate— Ellsworth complained; but there was a second to the previous Question 83 to 79. Crawford moved a Call of the House; upon which a short debate was allowed— The call was made, and when the names were gone through, Wilde moved to suspend the call— The yeas and nays were taken and the call suspended 106 and 89. but the hour for Resolutions had passed away and the previous question could not be taken. There was afterwards some debate on the Bills reported from the Committee of the whole, on the State of the Union, and upon a private Bill— I went into the Senate Chamber, and gave Mr Webster a paper, which had been forwarded here from New-York for Joseph Blunt— Holmes of Maine was speaking upon a Resolution to Call upon the Secretary of the Treasury for a Tariff Bill, or for a list of indispensables in War. The yeas and nays were taken several times, and the question not finally decided— John C. Calhoun took this Morning his Seat as a Senator from
South-Carolina, having resigned his Office as Vice-President of the United States— W. C. Rives had also taken his Seat as a Senator from Virginia— I spoke with Mr Calhoun, and Mr Clay—and with Mrs White of Florida, who invited me to a party at her House next Monday Evening— When I returned to the House they were just about adjourning. Mr Everett asked me to attend a Meeting of the Massachusetts Delegation at his lodgings this Evening which I did. The two Senators D. Webster and N. Silsbee, and the members of the House Bates, Briggs, Choate, Dearborn, Everett, Grennell, Hodges, Kendall, Nelson and Reed were present— Appleton and Davis absent. The object was a consultation upon the course to be pursued with regard to the Tariff-Bill, reported by the Committee of Ways and Means— The opinion was unanimous that its passage should be opposed; but no hope could be entertained by any one that the passage of it in the House could be prevented— There were some feeble hopes expressed that it might be defeated in the Senate— It was remarked that the protective system would be abandoned by the Kentucky Delegation— Everett asked me, if I thought Mr. Clay would be again a Candidate for the Presidency.— I said no doubt, if he could, with any prospect of success—of which there was at present none— W. C. Greenleaf got home.
5. V.15. Saturday.

In the House a bill reported by the Judiciary Committee, for continuing the Office of Reporter of the decisions of the Supreme Court of the United States with a Salary of 1000 dollars a year, came up at the second reading— Mr. Ellsworth of the Judiciary Committee wished it to pass without the delay of going into a Committee of the whole— But there is a Rule of the House that every motion or proposition touching a tax or charge upon the People, shall be first discussed in Committee of the whole. The Speaker decided that this Bill came within the Spirit of the Rule— Wickliffe reminded him that at the last Session he had decided the opposite way on a case precisely the same in principle; but he denied it and there was no record of the decision— I wished to have a record made of this decision, and therefore took an appeal from it; but after some discussion, finding the sense of the House generally in favour of the decision, and some difference of opinion among the oldest members upon the practice, I withdrew my appeal— It was however renewed by Arnold of Tennessee to have the decision recorded upon the Journals— The decision was affirmed by yeas and nays 162 to 14.— Although I had withdrawn my appeal, I voted against the decision, which as one of construction upon the Rule was wrong; and which Stevenson would have decided next week the other way, if it had come up in the shape of a party question— This debate however consumed the hour allotted to Resolutions; so that Polk’s previous question upon the Tariff Bill, could not be taken up— A few private Bills were discussed till 3. O’Clock when the House adjourned— The weather was this day nearly at Summer heat. I found myself so weak and languid under it, that for great part of the Evening I was unable to write. In the latter part of it I recovered so that the whole Evening was not wasted.
6. V:30. Sunday.

Dr Huntt was here this Morning— At St. John’s Church, Mr Hawley read the Morning Prayer for the second Sunday after Christmas—not for the Epiphany, and preached from Job. 16.22. “When a few years are come, then I shall go the way, whence I shall not return,” a New-Years Discourse upon Life, Death, and Eternity— He pointed out a discrimination between the Meaning of the words eternal and everlasting, the latter of which he said applied to the future, and to things which had a beginning. Mr Hawley’s Sermon was minatory, and he thought far the greater part of his Auditors,
were destined to everlasting punishment— After Church I had visits from Mr Gray of Boston, and Mr Lawrence of New-York— They made some enquiries concerning the Treaties with France of 1800 and 1803. After dinner, at the Presbyterian Church heard Mr Smith, from Matthew. 22, 1–14. The Parable of the Marriage of the king’s Son, and the wedding Garment. Evening fully occupied.
7. IV:45. Monday.

Met the Committee of Manufactures this Morning at ten— Worthington absent— J. S. Barbour present only a few minutes— The rest came in irregularly from ten to eleven, and sat in desultory general Conversation till Noon, the hour of Noon; the time of Meeting of the House. Adjourned without agreeing upon any time for the next Meeting. In the House, the Resolution to take up the Tariff-Bill, reported by the Committee of Ways and Means, on and every day after Monday next, till further order came up— There had been a second to Polk’s Motion for the previous Question last Friday, by which he had cut himself off from making any Amendment— Denny moved a Call of the House—rejected— Crawford moved to lay the Resolution on the table—rejected, both by yeas and nays— The previous question was then carried— Evans of Maine asked the Speaker what would be the effect of the words next Monday, in the Resolution to which Stevenson answered in a pet that it would be for the House to decide— The Speaker could not undertake in advance to say what would be the effect of any Resolution offered to the House— The main Question was carried, and announced to be 118 to 82. I think by mistake—there not being I think 200 members in the House— It was past one when the Resolution was adopted; so that the day and hour, referred to in it can apply only to next Monday— No attempt was made to take up the Bill this day—but I have no doubt it will be taken up to-morrow— Sundry other Bills were acted upon; one of which only was debuted—the Bill for refunding certain duties collected by the Tariff Act of 1828.— Wickliffe and Lewis Williams spoke against it— Burges and Drayton in its favour.— Adjourned without taking a Question— I went into the Senate Chamber, and heard Mr Clay close a Speech upon his Land-bill— I found by enquiry that the Bill in favour of Lobdell, was now before the Senate— I was this Evening not well— I received a Letter from M. Lord, at Boston—with a copy of the Second Edition of Dermot MacMorrogh— I lament its publication—
8. IV:45. Tuesday.

At the House, Petitions and Resolutions were called for— Several Resolutions were offered bearing upon the Subjects likely to be discussed in the House, and among them a Resolution for the Appointment by Ballot of a Committee of 24. Members, one from each State, with Instructions to report upon a great variety of Objects relating to the relative amount of the Collection and expenditure of the Revenue in the several States— They are preceded by a long preamble stating the complaints made both in and out of Congress that the collection and expenditure of the Revenues have been and are partial and unequal, and that these Complaints have been reiterated, till one of the States has undertaken to annul the Laws, and threatens to secede from the Union— They were offered by Mr Burges of Rhode-Island, who said he did not wish them to be now discussed, but laid on the table and printed.— Mr Wilde of Georgia made some remarks as intending to move to strike out the Preamble— But the Speaker pronounced all debate upon them now to be out of order— When the unfinished business of yesterday came up, Verplanck moved the suspension of it, to go into Committee of the Whole House on the State of the Union— The
The object was to take up the Tariff Bill— M’Kennan, objected that by the Resolution of yesterday the consideration of the Tariff had been postponed till Monday next, but the motion to go into Committee of the whole was carried— Wayne in the Chair— A fruitless effort was made to take up Root’s Resolution for an Amendment of the Constitution— The Tariff Bill prevailed and was read through— Whereupon Mr Verplanck rose and in a short and modest Speech, said he wished to introduce at once into discussion the details of the Bill— The principles had been sufficiently discussed at the last Session— The Bill at that time had reduced the revenue by several millions— It was now desirable to reduce it five or six Millions more; which was the object of this Bill— When he finished Mr Huntington of Connecticut moved that the Committee should rise—which was accordingly done; and the house adjourned— Walking homewards I overtook Mr Angell, one of the Van Buren members from New-York who accosted me, and had some conversation with me upon the weather, and upon the climate of Otsego.— Evening unwell— There were two New-Orleans Battle Balls.
9. V. Wednesday.

Mr Raymond brought me a Letter of Introduction from William L. Stone— He is concerned in a Manufactory of Flint-glass at Brooklyn on Long-Island: he comes to deprecate the proposition in the Tariff Bill reported by the Committee of Ways and Means, to take off the duty of two cents a pound upon flint glass— He says that the British Government give a bounty of a penny a Pound upon flint glass of their own manufacture, and that if the duty here is repealed the manufacture will be destroyed— He said Mr Bergen was his Representative; and through him though a Jackson man, he had obtained an introduction to Mr Hoffman, who had promised him, if he could prove that the British Government gave this bounty, he would move to have the duty here continued— The bounty he said was a matter of public notoriety, but he did not know whether he should be able to prove it— I told him he had done right to engage the aid of Mr Hoffman, and if he would propose the amendment to the Bill, restoring the duty it would pass—and that he might depend upon every assistance that it might be in my power to give him— At the House, A Bill for the relief of Jotham Lincoln, Administrator was reported by the Committee of Claims to whom I had yesterday obtained the reference of his Petition with the accompanying papers— The Bill was read a first and second time; referred to the Committee of the whole, and made the order of the day for to-morrow— Before one the House went into Committee of the Whole on the State of the Union—the Tariff Bill was taken up, and Mr Huntington made a Speech of two hours against it— He was followed by Mr Ingersoll, now the solitary member of the Committee of Ways and Means, opposed to the reported Bill— He was unwell, and soon gave way to a motion for the Committee to rise—the House soon after adjourned. Mr Hoffman came up to me and we had an hour’s conversation upon the proposed Tariff-Bill. He professes to be a radical, and has all the contracted prejudices of that political Sect. He has considerable Talent and some power of Eloquence; but his whole system of Government is comprized in the maxim of leaving money in the Pockets of the People— This is always the high road to popularity, and it is always travelled by those who have not resolution, intelligence and energy to attempt the exploration of any other. Yet it appears to me that Hoffman is now somewhat distrustful of it himself, and would take another road if he dared.
10. V. Thursday.

I am suffering with a ceaseless catarrhal cough, and with local partial inflammations, which afflict me much and in part disable me from labour;—but I yet trudge and drudge on with them as well as I can— At the House, they soon went into Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, and took up the Tariff-Bill— Mr Ingersoll finished his Speech of about two hours, and was followed by Mr Crawford, for about an hour, also against the Bill. Mr Ellsworth of Connecticut then moved the Committee to rise— It was carried by a vote of 70 to 63. counted by Tellers. The House then adjourned near four— I had company to dine; the names in the margin 15 at table, the Ladies absent. The weather has become intensely cold; and I found the walk from the Capitol home very distressing— I have been accustomed to brave the severity of the Seasons, and even at St. Petersbourg, walked before Sunrise in the heart of winter; without regard to the state of the Thermometer— The suffering of this day should teach me that I can no longer trifle with the atmosphere, even in this climate.

11. V. Friday. I was obliged to ride this day, to and from the Capitol— Horace Everett offered a Resolution of enquiry, which was referred to the Committee of Manufactures, to report, why the documents exhibiting the state of the manufactures, laid before Congress at their last Session, and ordered by a Resolution of the House of 28 May last to be printed, have not been printed? I stated the reason: because they were so voluminous, and because the returns were incomplete; some of them having not been even received till after the close of the last Session. Still the Resolution was referred, and I notified the members of the Committee except Mr Horn, who was not in the House to meet at ten to-morrow-Morning— The House gave the day to private business— Claim of the Inhabitants of East-Florida— Joseph M. White the delegate from the Territory, made a very earnest Speech in their favour— He was very anxious to obtain my vote for the Bill, but I could not be satisfied of its justice and voted against it. I was very unwell this evening, suffering in consequence of my exposure to the cold gale of yesterday in walking from the Capitol home.

12. VI:15. Saturday. I was barely able to attend the Committee of Manufactures, and the House— In Committee—Horn and Worthington absent—Hoffman, Findlay, Condict and Barbour present— I offered a Resolution, calling upon the Secretary of the Treasury for a list of Articles on which for the most part, a reduction of impost duties may be made, without injuriously affecting the existing manufacturing establishments— It was opposed by Hoffman and Barbour, and postponed till Monday next for a full Committee. I was instructed to enclose copies of the Resolution adopted yesterday, to the Clerk and the Printer of the House, for information upon which the Committee may be enabled to report.— I read several Letters from Manufacturers, complaining of the reported Tariff Bill— Barbour objected even to the reading of the Letters, but the Committee did hear them— In the House, the discussions were upon private Bills— A sharp debate arose upon a Bill for the relief of the legal representatives of Matthew Lyon—to repay them for the fine which he did not pay, upon his
conviction under the Sedition Law— On the discussions upon this Bill I take of course no part, and am in no condition now to take a part if I would— I was extremely unwell, and narrowly escaped fainting in the House— I came home and sent for Dr Huntt, who came and prescribed for my complaints.

13. VIII. Sunday.— I was up twice in the night, and confined the whole of this day to my chamber. Dr. Huntt was here and prescribed— All my labours are suspended; even to that of keeping up the current of my Diary.— Clementina Vail died this morning of a consumption— Dr. Huntt who attended her gave us an account of her illness.

14. VII. Monday.— Confined the whole day to my chamber, with extreme debility; unable to read or write, and almost to stand. The only part of my occupations which I have not intermitted is the reading of four chapters form the Scriptures—now the story of Joseph in the Book of Genesis— Dr Huntt was here— This was the first day that I have missed attendance in the House of Representatives, when in Washington since I have been a member— And when Sorrows come, they come not single Spies, but by Battalions— My Son John is also confined to his chamber with cramps in the Stomach, and alarming palpitations of the heart, and my wife is afflicted with her obstinate, and unintermitted racking cough— Time hangs heavy upon my Spirits—and Life scarcely feels like a blessing. I sent a message to the members of the Committee of Manufactures, to inform them of my inability to attend their Meeting.

15. VII:30. Tuesday— Still confined to the chamber, Easy Chair, and Settee, with boils breaking out upon me— My Son John is still confined to his chamber, and my wife is no better— Day slips off after day, and all the useful occupations of my life are suspended— Unanswered Letters accumulate upon my hands, and the vanity of all human concerns dwells like a dead weight upon the Soul.

16. VII. Wednesday.— I lie hour after hour awake in the morning before daylight, with a mind fretting at its own inanity— My wife and Son are both very ill— I was this day so far recovered as to be able to attend the Committee of Manufactures, and the House—Hoffman, Findlay and Barbour were present in Committee—Condict, Horn and Worthington absent— Read the Letters from the Clerk and Printer of the House concerning the Manufacture documents— Discussion upon the Report to be made to the House— Hoffman wished to screw the Clerk and Printer— I was averse to this and proposed to report the Letters of the Clerk and Printer, with a single observation. Findlay concurred with me. I produced again my projected Resolution, calling upon the Secretary of the Treasury, for a List of Articles upon which six Millions of duties may be reduced without prejudiced to existing establishments— Hoffman again talked it down— Finding it useless to press the subject in Committee, I offered the Resolution in the House, and another of the same purport addressed to the President of the United States. By the rules of the House they lie over one day— The President’s Message against Nullification, with Proclamations, Ordinance &c was presented to the House. R. H. Wilde of Georgia moved to postpone the consideration of it till to-morrow; but this motion was rejected— Williams of North-Carolina moved the reference of the Message and Documents to the Committee of the whole on the State of the Union— Stewart of Pennsylvania moved reference to a select Committee of
one member from each State—neither of these motions prevailed. W. S. Archer of Virginia moved the reference to the Committee on the Judiciary Committee, of which John Bell of Tennessee is Chairman; and this was carried. 25000 copies of the Message and Documents were ordered to be printed, on motion of Arnold of Tennessee— I came home after the house adjourned; and kept my chamber, unable to write.

17. VIII. Thursday.— Sleepless and feverish Night— My wife with a burning fever, and my Son John so ill, that Dr. Huntt was called up to him, and bled him copiously, about Midnight— I rode to and from the Capitol— Hubbard of New Hampshire, reported from the Committee on Revolutionary Pensions, a Bill to establish a Pension-Office, and to authorize the Appointment of a Commissioner of Pensions— Wilde of Georgia, from the Committee of Ways and Means, reported a Resolution of reference to the Committee of Public Lands, of certain enquiries concerning increased appropriations required for the Land-Office— Wickliffe moved an Amendment that the Committee should have power to send for persons and Papers— Resolution Adopted— Hogan of New-York moved a long Resolution for enquiry by the Committee on Naval Affairs, for numerous restrictions upon Officers of the Navy in command, to prevent peculation—with a contingent power to the Committee to send for persons and papers— Adopted— My Resolutions for Calls upon the Secretary of the Treasury, and the President were opposed by Hoffman until the expiration of the hour and the call for the Orders of the day— The Tariff Bill was then taken up in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Wayne of Georgia in the Chair, and debated till near four O’Clock— Edward Everett returned to his lodgings in the Carriage with me— I am yet utterly helpless.

18. VII. Friday.— Another sleepless and feverish Night— My wife suffering also with a violent fever, and incessant cough, the whole Night— I attended the House— A message was received from the President, with copies of instructions to our Ministers in France, relating to claims for spoliations since September 1800, and their correspondence on the subject, not before communicated. Referred to the Committee on Foreign Affairs— Plummer of Mississippi, moved the House to reconsider the Resolution offered yesterday by Wilde, relating to increased Appropriations for the Land-Office, and adopted—and then Plummer moved that the consideration of his motion to reconsider should be postponed till to-morrow— My two Resolutions were again opposed by Hoffman till the expiration of the hour.— My Resolution for a Call upon the President has been ludicrously misprinted— I was obliged to explain it to the House— Nuckolls of South-Carolina was at his request by Letter excused from further service upon two Committees— The reason for the request alledged, is ill-health— The real reason is the attitude assumed by South-Carolina, towards the Government of the Union— Nuckolls is a nullifier— At one, Verplanck, Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, moved to go into Committee of the whole on the Union, to take up the Tariff Bill— Elisha Whittlesey Chairman of the Committee of Claims, objected that Fridays and Saturdays were by the Rules of the House set apart for private business. The Speaker decided that by the rule itself, private business was the order of those days, unless otherwise determined by a majority of the House— And the House, by yeas and nays 96 to 83. voted to go into Committee of the whole upon the Union to take up the Tariff-Bill— M’Kennan of Pennsylvania, made in Committee a Speech against it— I took Edward Everett to his lodgings— In the evening I had a visit from Charles J.
Ingersoll, of Philadelphia, whom I received in my chamber— I continue in such a prostration of bodily strength that I can scarcely walk across the chamber.
19. VII.30. Saturday

The extreme violence of disease, of my wife and Son abated, but with another long, fever-heated, and almost sleepless night; from which I rise totally disabled for all action of body or mind; undergoing operations of medicine, and smarting with the ceaseless pain of boils and sores— At the House Wickliffe of Kentucky moved that from this time forward the hour to which the House shall daily stand adjourned, shall be eleven O’Clock A.M.—but at the motion of Ralph Ingersoll of Connecticut the consideration of this Resolution was postponed till next Saturday. A Resolution was adopted offered by T. H. Hall of North Carolina, directing the Clerk to have the ratifications of the federal Constitution by the Conventions of the several States, printed for the use of the house— Hoffman finished his Speech against my two Resolutions, and I replied till the expiration of the hour. Stewart of Pennsylvania proposed Amendments to my Resolutions; to which I could not accede— A message was received from the President, with the fourth annual report of the Board of Inspectors of the Penitentiary in the District of Columbia—referred to the Committee on the District. The Tariff Bill was again taken up in Committee of the whole on the Union, and debated till the adjournment— Edward Everett introduced to me Captain Byam Martin, of the British Royal Navy— I took Everett home— I had some conversation with Mr Clay, on a Seat outside the Bar of the House.— Evening idle—Bed fitted up for me in chamber adjourning my Study; but the chamber was too cold— General John Adair, a member of the House from Kentucky, was suddenly taken very ill last Night— Huntt attends him— Mr and Mrs William S. Smith, were here this Evening—
20. VII.30. Sunday.

My Son John blessed be God is much recovered, but his disease, an excessive and almost suffocating palpitation of the heart, leaves forebodings which greatly distress me— My wife is recovering, though yet exceedingly ill; and I myself am cast down in strength to such a degree that I was unable to attend public worship, or to write a line though confined to my chamber the whole day.— I had a long morning visit from John Sergeant, and one in the Evening from W. S. Smith— Sergeant, is in full and profitable practice at the bar, and is here attending the Session of the Supreme Court of the United States— But he has fallen into unpopular politics and is soured in temper.— He was nominated by the National Republican Convention at Baltimore last December, and by the Convention of young men at Washington last May, as a Candidate for the Office of Vice-President of the United States; with Henry Clay as their Candidate for President— These nominations have totally failed, and Sergeant feels severely the disappointment— Sergeant is an honest, and very able man, of a class that never can be favourites of the People— It is his misfortune to be associated in this nomination with Mr. Clay, whose vaulting ambition has overleaped itself. The aspirants to the Presidency ruin their own prospects by the precipitation with which they rush to their prize— This has been especially the mistake of Mr Clay, who with more eloquence and much more management than Sergeant has less real talent, a weaker judgment, and far less consistency of principle— The last ten days have been to me one long agony, without remission. The only ability left me is that of reading, and the mind is too much preoccupied with alarm and affliction, for reading with any profit.
21. VIII. Monday.

Slept in the miniature chamber adjoining my Study; a supportably quiet Night—the first of eleven— Still unable to write— Morning visit from General Dearborn. Attended at the House—Monday; the weekly day for receiving Petitions and Memorials— I presented a Petition from Merchants at Plymouth, for an Appropriation to build a Custom-house and Post-Office in that Town. Referred to the Committee on Commerce— Among the petitions presented was one by Coulter of Pennsylvania from inhabitants of the District of Columbia, praying for the gradual abolition of Slavery in the District, and for the prohibition of the Slave-trade in it— Referred to the District Committee— M’Duffie presented a Resolution of the Legislature of South-Carolina, proposing that a Convention of the States be called to consider and determine questions of disputed power, which have arisen between the States and the general Government— Stewart presented Resolutions of the Legislature of Pennsylvania against the Tariff bill now before the House: and Burges, Resolutions of the Legislature of Rhode-Island against the reduction of the duties on imports— A message from the President, with the annual report of the Director of the Mint was received— The debate in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, upon the Tariff-bill was resumed— Opposed by E. T. White of Louisiana—and supported by Polk of Tennessee— I took Edward Everett home— Charles A. Davis and Henry Brooks are in the City— Evening visit from R. Peters— My wife and Son, recovering.
22. VII. Tuesday.

Mr Jacob Bigelow brought me a Letter from Louis M’Lane, Secretary of the Treasury, making certain enquiries of me, of my knowledge concerning a claim of the heirs of Francis Cazeau, upon which I am convinced that a filthy fraud has heretofore been predicted upon Congress, and perhaps upon the heirs of Cazeau— Mr Bigelow, who now represents those heirs, and who proffers a claim upon this Government in their behalf, is extremely anxious to obtain from me a written Statement of what I knew of the manoeuverings between Stewart of New-York and Grubb, in this affair and I told Mr Bigelow, I would make a written Statement if requested by the Secretary of the Treasury— This is the requisition— At the House, I made the Report from the Committee of Manufactures on the delay in printing the documents relating to manufactures returned at the last Session— Edward Everett from the Committee on the Library reported a Bill to provide for the publication of the Documentary History of the American Revolution—twice read and referred to the Committee of the whole on the Union— The Tariff-Bill was again taken up in committee of the whole. John Reed and Nathan Appleton made Speeches against it. Several successive motions for the Committee to rise failed. at last one succeeded. Speight of North-Carolina immediately moved to go into Committee again— A motion to adjourn was rejected by yeas and nays 68 to 76.— Vinton of Ohio moved a Call of House, and pending that question the motion to adjourn was renewed and again rejected by yeas and nays 71 to 75— The motion for a Call of the House again recurred, and after some debate, Verplanck Chairman of the Ways and Means who has charge of the Bill, moved to adjourn for this time, but begged of the Members of the House to come prepared to sit it out to-morrow— It was now six O’Clock, and the adjournment passed without Opposition— I came home and immediately retired to bed.
23. VII. Wednesday.

My Son John was again very ill in the Night and was again copiously bled by Dr. Huntt. My wife is still unable to leave her bed, and extremely ill— My own Condition is little better than it has been for the last ten days— At the House, a Message was received from the President, with a Report from the Secretary of State, and a List of Appointments made from Members of Congress since the 13th. of April 1826. and another List of such appointments made from the 3d. of March 1825 to the 13th. of April 1826— The consideration of my Resolutions offered on the 16th. was resumed and Hoffman made a speech against them, to which I replied, in a few words— The Tariff-bill was again debated in Committee of the whole— N. Appleton finished his Speech against it, and was followed by Horace Everett on the same side— The Committee rose about 5. P.M. Speight scolded the house into Committee again— The yeas and nays on questions of adjournment and calls of the house, were taken four or five times. Everett finished his Speech, and Wilde began a very Wild one in favour of the Bill— He appealed especially to the Southern, and New-York Van Buren Members, and intimated very distinctly that if the Van Buren men, expected to obtain any Southern votes for the little magician, they must abandon the protective system and vote for this bill. He alluded to Mr Clay as having lost his popularity throughout the Union, by his connection with the last Administration— The House adjourned at 9. in the Evening; leaving his Speech unfinished. I asked him after the adjournment for an explanation of this— I remained in the house all day, without dinner, and came home fasting to bed.

24. VII. Thursday.— At the House, a Message received from the President, with a ratified Convention of 14. October 1832 with the king of the two Sicilies—and a Letter from the Secretary of the Treasury with a statement of unavailable funds— Stewart of Pennsylvania moved an Amendment to the Resolution offered by me on the 16th. of a call upon the Secretary of the Treasury— Clay of Alabama moved to lay the whole on the Table, which was carried by yeas and nays 95 to 72. Kennon of Ohio in the debate made an abusive allusion to Dermot MacMorrogh, and was called to order by the Speaker— The Tariff bill further discussed in Committee of the whole. Wilde concluded his Speech—recanted some of his assertions made last Evening—and apologised to N. Appleton and to me. Vinton’s Speech against the Bill—bold and vehement. The Committee rose, but at Speight’s rallying order the House went into Committee again— Vinton finished his Speech; at one passage of it M’Duffie interrupted him with a cry of “Robespierre,” which was followed by a general hiss— Carson argufied to the house that the hiss was at Vinton, and not at M’Duffie— Vinton without losing his temper, corrected the misrepresentation of his words. Watmough interposed to conciliate— Calls to order all around— Watmough moved the Committee to rise—refused— Watmough spoke against the Bill— Arnold of Tennessee began a Speech against the Bill— Committee rose and the House adjourned shortly before 9. P.M. I dined upon Sandwiches in the Chamber of the Committee of Manufactures. Very unwell. Francis Thomas of Maryland spoke to me with a tone of kindness and good-humour. He had exchanged no civility with me before since the Reports of the Bank-investigating Committee.
25. VII:30. Friday—

Dreams of a man to whom life becomes a burden—Atrabilious— My wife—my Son, myself, in sickness and in sorrow.— Morning visits from Mr Lorman, and Mr Brown of Baltimore— At the House, I presented two Petitions from Middleborough for Mails to Plymouth and New Bedford.
Thomas of Louisiana moves the suspension of the 13th. rule of the House, and to leave to the discretion of the Speaker the admission of Strangers into the House without the Bar. Message from the President, with report of an Officer upon inspection of works for the improvement of the Navigation of the Ohio and Mississippi Rivers. Boon of Indiana presented Resolutions and a preamble by the Legislature of that State, severe and indignant against the South-Carolina nullification proceedings: approving in unqualified terms the President’s Proclamation, and glorifying him in proportion— Boon, who would himself be a nullifier if he dared, did not ask for the reading of the Resolutions, and they were not read— Mr Clay’s Bill for distributing among the States the proceeds of the public Lands came from the Senate—read twice and referred to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Howard’s motion to adjourn over to Monday, at the motion of Elisha Whittlesey, laid on the table— Tariff Bill, in Committee of the whole— Arnold finished his Speech—nearly three hours—Ardent—vehement—full of noble and Patriotic Sentiment— Irwin of Ohio followed— Cambreleng—Pouting, and flouting; and flirting between him and Wilde about Van Burenism— Vinton explained— Kirk came for me at 5 O’Clock P.M— I ordered him to come again at 8. but the Committee rose at the motion of Burges after 6— I came home with N. Appleton, and E. Everett in Joseph Abbotts hack.
26. VII. Saturday.

Mr Bradley and Mr Grammer were here about the proposed application of the Franklin Insurance Company, for authority to insure on marine risks, and on lives— I thought a call and determination of the Stockholders necessary to warrant the application, and I disinclined to its being made— At the House, the 13th. Rule was amended so that the Speaker, or any member may admit persons into the Hall, without the Bar— It was at the motion of P. Thomas, of Louisiana. The object is to admit the Ladies— Tariff-bill in Committee of the whole. Burges spoke against it, about two hours—he had not finished, but after 3. Grennell moved that the Committee should rise—carried 75 to 50. Neither Speight nor Polk was in the house— Adjourned. I had ordered Kirk to come for me with the Carriage; but after spending half an hour in the Library, I walked home— My wife and my Son, blessed be God are better, and my own fever-boils have broken, and seem to be subsiding.

27. VII. Sunday.— My wounds continue healing, but my weakness of body and mind, still greatly disables me. I attended this morning at the Presbyterian Church, and heard Mr Smith from Psalm 50.22. “Now, consider this, ye that forget God, lest I tear you in pieces, and there be none to deliver.” Wrote a few lines this afternoon, but all my business has run sixteen days in arrear; and much of it can never be retrieved— I read a Chapter of Gleig’s History of the Bible, and two or three Letters of Prince Puchler-Muskau; but the capacity of attention and the Memory fail with age and sickness. I read last Evening General John Armstrong’s notice of my Eulogy upon the life and character of James Monroe. The pamphlet is anonymous.— Armstrong never dared to publish the Newburgh Letters with his name— He was annoyed by the passage of the Eulogy in which there is a censure upon his blundering military pedantry in the Summer of 1814. when he was Secretary of War, and he has published a pamphlet in vindication of his own conduct and of the bitterest abuse upon Mr. Monroe, and upon me— There is nothing in it that I think needs reply.

28. VII. Monday.— Began writing again, though still much disabled.— At the House, H. A. S. Dearborn, presented the petition of Delia Tudor, widow of William Tudor, for commutation of his half pay as judge-Advocate general of the army in the War of the Revolution—referred to the Committee on Revolutionary claims. The Speaker presented a Memorial from the Legislative Council of the Territory of Michigan, praying to be admitted into the Union as a State— Referred to the Committee on the Territories. Petitions and Memorials absorbed the first hour of business— The Tariff-Bill was then resumed in Committee of the whole— Burges spoke three hours against it— Then Young of Connecticut about an hour—prevented by hoarseness from proceeding— The Committee refused to rise. Howard of Baltimore; for and against the Bill about an hour— W. B. Shepard of North-Carolina moved the Committee to rise— Carried—and the House at 1/2 past 6. adjourned by yeas and nays 85. to 75— Edward Everett mentioned an overture from Bell of Tennessee (Nullification) for a bargain to pass the Land-Bill, as an equivalent for the Tariff-Bill. John Reed proposed a Meeting, to-morrow morning, of the Massachusetts members of the House to consult thereon.
29. VII:30. Tuesday.

Messieurs Ellicott and Kennedy, called upon me, with a memorial from the permanent Committee of the New-York Tariff Convention, which is to be presented to the House to-morrow, by the Speaker— Meeting of the Massachusetts members of the House at 11. O’Clock in the Committee Room of the Committee of Commerce—Choate, Davis and Everett absent—all the rest present— Consultation; but no conclusion— In the House— Appleton’s call, on the Secretary of the Treasury for Statements debated— Wilde moved to lay it on the Table; rejected by yeas and nays 53 to 71.— Clay moved to postpone the Consideration of it to the 2d. of March ensuing—rejected 78 to 82. At the expiration of the hour, Verplanck moved the orders of the day; and to go into Committee of the whole on the Tariff-bill— Carried 94 to 67. W. B. Shepard of North-Carolina, made a very handsome Speech against the Bill— Followed by Slade of Vermont— Disorderly Noises—chiefly made by Dixon H. Lewis of Alabama—a Ton of a man— I. C. Bates, proposes a motion for the Committee to rise, after multitudes of others, fruitlessly made— Verplanck offers an Amendment to the Bill—to reduce the duties proposed by the Bill, upon Teas— Carried— The Committee by a vote of 64 to 60 rose, and the House at half past eight P.M. adjourned— The Resolutions of the Legislature of Massachusetts against the Tariff-Bill were this day received by the members from the State.
30. VII. Wednesday. Feeble.

Rainy day.— At the House I presented the Resolutions of the Legislature of Massachusetts, upon the Tariff-Bill— They were read— Ordered to be printed, and committed to the Committee of the whole on the Union— After this vote had passed, Wilde of Georgia moved its re-consideration— I moved that the Memorial of the Permanent Committee of the New-York Convention should be read— The Speaker produced it, and it was read in part, till nearly the expiration of the hour; when the reading was suspended—it was ordered to be printed, and referred to the Committee of the whole on the Union— A message was received from the president with a Report from the Postmaster General, of members of Congress appointed to Offices in the Post-Office Department, since the 13th. of April 1826— N. Appleton’s Resolution was superseded again, by the Tariff-Bill in Committee of the whole— I. C. Bates made a Speech against it— Then Dutee J. Pearce—followed by Root and Jenifer. Much disorder, particularly in the effort to silence Pearce, but without success. Past 8. Banks moved Committee to rise 62. 60. Adjourned 1/2 past 8.

31. VII. Thursday.— At the House— Wilde’s motion for reconsideration debated. John Davis—Edward Everett— I spoke harshly of Wilde— Debate superseded by the expiration of the hour— Tariff Bill in Committee of the whole. Banks and Evans of Maine—two excellent Speeches against the Bill— Leonard Jarvis of Maine, in its favour— Burd of Pennsylvania, ludicrous, Question taken upon striking out the duties on Teas and Coffee— Carried. 69 to 64.— I was out of the house at the moment of the vote— Campbell P. White of New-York offers Amendments to be printed— Committee rose. House adjourned at 5. P.M— In the Evening I received Stansbury’s report of my remarks.
Day. Entirely discomposed by the sickness of myself, and of my family.
